info.title: Crosswork Network Controller IETF L2VPN NM API
info.description:
The YANG module defines a generic network configuration
model for Layer 2 VPN services common across all of the
vendor implementations.

Copyright (c) 2020 IETF Trust and the persons identified as
authors of the code.  All rights reserved.

Redistribution and use in source and binary forms, with or
without modification, is permitted pursuant to, and subject to
the license terms contained in, the Simplified BSD License set
forth in Section 4.c of the IETF Trust's Legal Provisions
Relating to IETF Documents
(https://trustee.ietf.org/license-info).

vpn-service-vpn-id.name: vpn-service-vpn-id
vpn-service-vpn-id.description: Refers to unique identifier for the L2NM.

vpn-id.description: Refers to unique identifier for the L2NM. (leaf)

modified.description:
Devices and other services this service has modified directly or
indirectly (through another service). (non-presence)

directly-modified.description:
Devices and other services this service has explicitly
modified. (non-presence)

items.description:
A list of managed devices this service instance has manipulated.

This leaf is obsolete. Use 'modified' instead. (leaf-list)

queue-item.description:
When a service is committed through the commit queue, these
fields act as references regarding the state of this service
instance. In the worst case scenario, a service instance is
in the 'failed' state. This means that parts of the queued
commit failed.

If a service gets committed through the commit queue and the
commit fails, the backpointers in the service data are
followed and the affected service instances are updated and
set to the 'failed' state.

Depending on the nature of the failure, different techniques
to reconcile the service can be used.

- Make sure the commit queue is blocked to not interfere
  with the error recovery procedure.
  Do a sync-from on the non-completed device(s) and then
  re-deploy the failed service(s) with the
  'reconcile' option to reconcile original data,
  i.e., take control of that data. This option
  acknowledges other services controlling the same data.
  The reference count will indicate how many services control
  the data. Release any queue lock that was created.

- Make sure the commit queue is blocked to not interfere
  with the error recovery procedure.
  Use un-deploy with the no-networking option on the
  service and then do sync-from on the non-completed
  device(s). Make sure the error is fixed and then
  re-deploy the failed service(s) with the
  'reconcile' option. Release any queue lock
  that was created.

In the 'failed' state, these fields are reset if a new
commit queue transaction is affecting this service, or
the service is re-deployed, or these fields are deleted
using the specific purge action.
In other cases the 'failed' state will remain. (list)

id.description:
If the queue item in the commit queue refers to this service
this is the queue number. (leaf)

failed-device.description:
If the 'status' leaf is 'failed', this list contains detailed
information on the devices that were responsible for the
error of the commit queue item. (list)

config-data.description:
The configuration data that was rejected by the device
in XML format. (leaf)

error.description: The error returned by the device. (leaf)

private.description: NCS service related internal data stored here. (non-presence)

diff-set.description:
Internal node use by NCS service manager to remember
the reverse diff for a service instance. This is the
data that is used by FastMap (leaf)

forward-diff-set.description:
Internal node use by NCS service manager to remember
the forwards diff for a service instance. This data is
is used to produce the proper 'get-modifications' output (leaf)

items.description: A list of managed devices this service instance has manipulated. (leaf-list)
A list of NED identities this service instance has manipulated. (leaf-list)
A list of services this service instance has manipulated. (leaf-list)
A list of LSA services this service instance has manipulated. (leaf-list)

property-list.description: FASTMAP service instance data used by the service implementation. (non-presence)

latest-commit-params.description:
Latest transactions commit parameters are stored there, these are
used in reactive-re-deploy actions that must have the same
parameters as the original service commit. (leaf)

latest-u-info.description:
Latest transactions user info is stored there, these are
used in reactive-re-deploy actions that must be performed by
a user with the same user info. (leaf)

type.description: What type of log entry is this. (leaf)

level.description: What level this log entry has. (leaf)

custom-template.description: Custom templates to apply when device is ready (list)

variable.description: Variables to bind when applying template one time (list)

iteration.description: Apply custom template multiple times with iteration (list)

variable.description: Variables to bind when applying template in iteration (list)

custom-template.description: Custom templates to apply when device is ready (list)

variable.description: Variables to bind when applying template one time (list)

iteration.description: Apply custom template multiple times with iteration (list)

variable.description: Variables to bind when applying template in iteration (list)

type.description: VPN signaling types. Only one signaling option can be given per VPN node (leaf)

ac-pw-list.description: List of AC and PW bindings. (list)

peer-addr.description: Peer IP address. Only one peer IP can be given. (leaf)

vc-id.description: VC label used to identify PW. (leaf)

id.description: Identifier of network access. Only one VPN id can be given for a VPN node. (leaf)

Interface-mtu.description:
Interface MTU, it is also known as the maximum
transmission unit or maximum frame size. When a
frame is larger than the MTU, it is broken down,
or fragmented, into smaller pieces by the
network protocol to accommodate the MTU of the
network (leaf)

ingress.description: Set the tag rewriting policy for this EFP (presence)
Set the tag rewriting policy for this EFP (presence)

component.description:
A component has a type and a list of states.  It is required
that the first plan component is of type ncs:self.  It is
also required that the first state of a component is ncs:init
and the last state is ncs:ready.  A service can in addition
to the 'self' component have any number of components. These
additional components will have types that are defined by
user specified YANG identities. (list)

type.description:
The plan component type is defined by an YANG identity.
It is used to identify the characteristics of a certain component.
Therefore, if two components in the same service are of the same
type they should be identical with respect to number, type and order
of their contained states. (leaf)

state.description:
A plan state represents a certain step or stage that a service needs
to execute and/or reach. It is identified as an YANG identity.
There are two predefined states ncs:init and ncs:ready which is the
first respectively last state of a plan component. (list)

status.description:
A plan state is always in one of three states 'not-reached' when
the state has not been executed, 'reached' when the state has been
executed and 'failed' it the state execution failed. (leaf)

when.description: The time this state was successfully reached or failed. (leaf)

service-reference.description:
If this component reflects the state of some other data, e.g
an instantiated RFS, an instantiated CFS or something else, this
optional field can be set to point to that instance (leaf)

create-cb.description:
indicate if a create callback should be registered
for this state (leaf)

create-force-commit.description:
Indicate if the current transaction should be commited before
running any later states. (leaf)

delete-cb.description:
indicate if a delete callback should be registered
for this state (leaf)

delete-force-commit.description:
Indicate if the current transaction should be commited before
running any later states. (leaf)

pre-conditions.description:
Pre-conditions for a state controls whether or not a
state should be executed. There are separate conditions
for the 'create' and 'delete' case. At create the
create conditions checked and if possible executed with
the ultimate goal for the state of having status
'reached'. At the 'delete' case the delete conditions
control whether the state changes should be deleted
with the ultimate goal of the state having status
'not-reached' (presence)

post-actions.description:
Post-actions are called after successful execution of a
state.  These are optional and there are separate
action that can be set for the 'create' and 'delete'
case respectively.

These actions are put as requests in the
side-effect-queue and are executed asynchronously with
respect to the original service transaction. (presence)

create-action-node.description:
This leaf identifies the node on which a specified
action resides. This action is called after this state
as got a 'reached' status. (leaf)

create-action-result-expr.description:
An action responds with a structured result. A certain
value could indicate an error or a successful result, e.g.
'result true'.

This statement describes an XPath expression to
evaluate the result of the action so that the
side-effect-queue can indicate action errors.

The result of the expression is converted to a boolean using
the standard XPath rules.  If the result is 'true' the action
is reported as successful, otherwise as failed.

The context for evaluating this expression is the
resulting xml tree of the action.

The set of namespace declarations are all available namespaces,
with the prefixes defined in the modules. (leaf)

delete-action-node.description:
This leaf identifies the node on which a specified
action resides. This action is called after this state
as got a 'not-reached' status. (leaf)

delete-action-result-expr.description:
An action responds with a structured result. A certain
value could indicate an error or a successful result, e.g.
'result true'.

This statement describes an XPath expression to evaluate the
result of the action so that the side-effect-queue can
indicate action errors.

The result of the expression is converted to a boolean using
the standard XPath rules.  If the result is 'true' the action
is reported as successful, otherwise as failed.

The context for evaluating this expression is the
resulting xml tree of the action.

The set of namespace declarations are all available namespaces,
with the prefixes defined in the modules. (leaf)

post-action-status.description:
This leaf is initially set to 'not-reached'.

If a post-action was specified, and returned
successfully, this leaf will be set to 'create-reached'
if the component is not back-tracking, and
'delete-reached' if it is back-tracking.

If the post-action did not return successfully, this
leaf is set to 'failed'. (leaf)

Devices and other services this service has modified directly or
indirectly (through another service). (non-presence)

directly-modified.description:
Devices and other services this service has explicitly
modified. (non-presence)

private.description: NCS service related internal data stored here. (non-presence)

the reverse diff for a service instance. This is the
data that is used by FASTMAP (leaf)

forward-diff-set.description:
Internal node use by NCS service manager to remember
the forwards diff for a service instance. This data is
is used to produce the proper 'get-modifications' output (leaf)

manipulated. (leaf-list)
A list of services this state has manipulated. (leaf-list)
A list of LSA services this service instance has manipulated. (leaf-list)

private.description: NCS service related internal data stored here. (non-presence)

property-list.description:
FASTMAP service component instance data used by the
service implementation. (non-presence)

id.description:
If the queue item in the commit queue refers to this service
this is the queue number. (leaf)

message.description: An explanatory message for the failing plan. (leaf)

log-entry.description: Reference to a service log entry with additional information. (leaf)

recommended-action.description: Recommended action to recover in case of error (leaf)

plan.description:
Every time the plan changes its structure, i.e., a
plan component is added or deleted, or a state is added or
deleted in a plan component, a copy of the old plan is stored
in the plan history list. (list)
